title: A Luxury Condo in Boston Now Costs Over $1 Million More Than it Did Last Year
text:
Tight housing supply in Boston despite a spate of new luxury development has driven home prices through the roof, data released Thursday shows.



The median condo price hit $4.25 million in the third quarter of 2019, a surge of 55% compared to a year ago, according to market data prepared by real estate agency Douglas Elliman and New York-based appraisal firm Miller Samuel. Put another way, the median condo buyer paid $1.51 million more this past summer than they did in 2018.

The report defines luxury as the top 10% of sales.



Boston’s high-end market stands in stark contrast to bigger coastal luxury hubs such as New York City and much of urban California, where top-end sales have slowed and average prices have declined over the past year.



As an example, there were only four-months worth of luxury condo supply in downtown Boston in the third quarter compared to a staggering 22-months worth of high-end apartment inventory in Manhattan, according to a separate report from the brokerage.



Boston’s townhouse market is even tighter, as the average house spent less than two months on the market in the third quarter.



“As the locals might say, the townhouse market in Downtown Boston is moving ‘wicked fast,’” said Jonathan Miller, chief executive of Miller Samuel and author of the report.



As a result, the median price for a townhouse—a category dominated by centuries-old brick row houses—was $1.352 million in the third quarter, up over 20% from a year ago.



Tight inventory poses a major challenge to sales moving forward, as buyers run out of options and surging prices rise out of people’s reach, issues that underlie a sales downturn in other parts of the country.



Greenwich, Connecticut, Sees Falling Inventory and Higher Prices



Elsewhere in New England, the luxury housing market in Greenwich, Connecticut, continued to stabilize, said Scott Elwell, a Douglas Elliman senior executive regional manager.



High-end deals were up slightly from a year ago, and the median home price jumped more than 10% to $6.11 million in the first quarter even as average house size dropped, according to a separate Douglas Elliman report Thursday.

Falling inventory has also helped prop up home prices in the affluent commuter town, where luxury listings are down over 20% from a year ago.



“The sharp drop in mortgage rates combined with sellers understanding market conditions” has helped buoy the market, Mr. Elwell said, specifically in the face of federal tax reform that weighed heavily on high-tax states like Connecticut since it was enacted in 2018.
